page.title: 04SHRIMPING IN BANKS/CROSSENS
page.content: SOUTHPORT SHRIMPS ARE FAMOUS AND FISHING AND SHRIMPING HAVE BEEN CARRIED OUT BY BANKS AND CROSSENS FISHERMEN FOR CENTURIES.TRACTORS HAVE NOW REPLACED THE HORSE AND CART BUT IT IS STILL A DIFFICULT JOB. SHRIMPERS SAILED OUT IN BOATS FROM CROSSENS SLUICE TO THE SEA.FISHERMEN COULD HANDNET FOR SHRIMPS,PLACING THEIR CATCH IN DEEP BASKETS CALLED "LEAPS".THE "CARTSHANKERS" USED A HORSE DRAWN CART TO LAY NETS. IN THE PAST FISHERMEN WOULD GO TO FISH SOMETIMES TWICE A DAY AND THEIR FAMILIES WOULD CLEAN,BOIL AND SORT THE SHRIMPS.MOST FISHERMEN'S WIVES USED TO GO ROUND TO HOUSES CARRYING BASKETS FULL OF SHRIMPS TO SELL.SOME ALSO WENT TO NEARBY MARKETS AND SHRIMPS WERE SOLD BY THE GILL OR IN PINT MEASURES. TODAY THE SHRIMPERS HAVE OTHER JOBS WHEN THEY ARE NOT FISHING.
